00022 /* This code was initially inspired by the wiring_serial module by David A. Mellis which
00023    used to be a part of the Arduino project. */ 
00024 
00025 #include "system.h"
00026 #include "serial.h"
00027 #include "settings.h"
00028 
00029 
00030 void printString(const char *s)
00031 {
00032   while (*s)
00033     serial_write(*s++);
00034 }
00035 
00036 // Print a string stored in PGM-memory
00037 void printPgmString(const char *s)
00038 {
00039   char c;
00040   while ((c = pgm_read_byte_near(s++)))
00041     serial_write(c);
00042 }

00044 // void printIntegerInBase(unsigned long n, unsigned long base)
00045 // { 
00046 //  unsigned char buf[8 * sizeof(long)]; // Assumes 8-bit chars. 
00047 //  unsigned long i = 0;
00048 // 
00049 //  if (n == 0) {
00050 //   serial_write('0');
00051 //   return;
00052 //  } 
00053 // 
00054 //  while (n > 0) {
00055 //   buf[i++] = n % base;
00056 //   n /= base;
00057 //  }
00058 // 
00059 //  for (; i > 0; i--)
00060 //   serial_write(buf[i - 1] < 10 ?
00061 //    '0' + buf[i - 1] :
00062 //    'A' + buf[i - 1] - 10);
00063 // }
00064 
00065 void print_uint8_base2(uint8_t n)
00066 { 
00067  unsigned char buf[8];
00068  uint8_t i = 0;
00069 
00070  for (; i < 8; i++) {
00071   buf[i] = n & 1;
00072   n >>= 1;
00073  }
00074 
00075  for (; i > 0; i--)
00076   serial_write('0' + buf[i - 1]);
00077 }
00078 
00079 void print_uint32_base10(unsigned long n)
00080 { 
00081   unsigned char buf[10]; 
00082   uint8_t i = 0;
00083   
00084   if (n == 0) {
00085     serial_write('0');
00086     return;
00087   } 
00088   
00089   while (n > 0) {
00090     buf[i++] = n % 10 + '0';
00091     n /= 10;
00092   }
00093     
00094   for (; i > 0; i--)
00095     serial_write(buf[i-1]);
00096 }
00097 
00098 void printInteger(long n)
00099 {
00100   if (n < 0) {
00101     serial_write('-');
00102     n = -n;
00103   }
00104   print_uint32_base10(n);
00105 }
00106 
00107 // Convert float to string by immediately converting to a long integer, which contains
00108 // more digits than a float. Number of decimal places, which are tracked by a counter,
00109 // may be set by the user. The integer is then efficiently converted to a string.
00110 // NOTE: AVR '%' and '/' integer operations are very efficient. Bitshifting speed-up 
00111 // techniques are actually just slightly slower. Found this out the hard way.
00112 void printFloat(float n)
00113 {
00114   if (n < 0) {
00115     serial_write('-');
00116     n = -n;
00117   }
00118 
00119   uint8_t decimals = settings.decimal_places;
00120   while (decimals >= 2) { // Quickly convert values expected to be E0 to E-4.
00121     n *= 100;
00122     decimals -= 2;
00123   }
00124   if (decimals) { n *= 10; }
00125   n += 0.5; // Add rounding factor. Ensures carryover through entire value.
00126     
00127   // Generate digits backwards and store in string.
00128   unsigned char buf[10]; 
00129   uint8_t i = 0;
00130   uint32_t a = (long)n;  
00131   buf[settings.decimal_places] = '.'; // Place decimal point, even if decimal places are zero.
00132   while(a > 0) {
00133     if (i == settings.decimal_places) { i++; } // Skip decimal point location
00134     buf[i++] = (a % 10) + '0'; // Get digit
00135     a /= 10;
00136   }
00137   while (i < settings.decimal_places) { 
00138      buf[i++] = '0'; // Fill in zeros to decimal point for (n < 1)
00139   }
00140   if (i == settings.decimal_places) { // Fill in leading zero, if needed.
00141     i++;
00142     buf[i++] = '0'; 
00143   }   
00144   
00145   // Print the generated string.
00146   for (; i > 0; i--)
00147     serial_write(buf[i-1]);
00148 }
